Rinne negative, Weber lateralised to right

Rinne negative, Weber lateralised to left

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents with unilateral right sided hearing loss. Examination is shown below. What will be the right-sided Rinne's test finding in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Rinne negative, Weber lateralised to right

questions.text: A 79-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for an elective total knee replacement. He lives by himself and performs all of his activities of daily living. His medical history includes degenerative joint disease, coronary heart disease, and hypertension. He has no history of psychiatric problems or alcohol and drug history. In the evening, several hours after an uneventful surgical procedure, the patient becomes diaphoretic and tachypneic. He is alert, but also agitated and confused, and cannot give full attention to the hospital staff and their questions. He does remember his name, but does not believe that he is in a hospital. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 22-year-old man with 2 days of fever, cough, sore throat, and runny nose comes to the OPD. Lung sounds are clear to auscultation. A nasopharyngeal swab is obtained. Naked viral particles are seen, and purified RNA molecules are extracted from these particles. Once introduced into human cells, the purified RNA molecules induce viral protein synthesis and viral genome replication. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rhinovirus

 

Lets diagnose from clinical vignette given:

 

  • Young man with fever, cough, sore throat, runny nose → features of an upper respiratory tract infection (common cold).
  • Clear lungs → rules out pneumonia.
  • Naked viral particles → excludes enveloped viruses.
  • Purified RNA alone is infectious → this means the virus is a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA virus (ssRNA+) because it can directly act as mRNA in host cells.
  • Rhinovirus (Picornavirus family) fits best.
  • Picornavirus; naked, positive-sense ssRNA.
  • Purified RNA is infectious (directly acts as mRNA).
  • Causes common cold with nasal symptoms, mild fever, sore throat.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV:

 

  • Retrovirus; enveloped, not naked.
  • RNA genome requires reverse transcriptase before protein synthesis → purified RNA alone is not infectious.

 

Option B. Influenza virus type A: 

 

  • Orthomyxovirus; enveloped, segmented negative-sense RNA.
  • Needs viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase; purified RNA alone is not infectious.

 

Option C. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV):

 

  • Paramyxovirus; enveloped, negative-sense RNA.
  • Requires polymerase; purified RNA is not infectious.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is evaluated in the clinic due to absence of her last 3 menstrual periods. The patient has also developed bilateral milky nipple discharge. Menarche was at age 13. Until now, she has had regular menses, lasting 4-5 days, every 28 days. The patient says she takes acetaminophen for occasional headaches and a medication that "stops the voices" in her head. BMI is 29 kg/m. Interruption of which of the following central nervous system pathways is the most likely cause of this patient's presenting symptoms?
What is the improper pairing between the anatomical limits of lymph nodes and the Level of lymph nodes?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Level 5: Cricoid to suprasternal notch

 

The neck lymph node levels are anatomically defined for staging head and neck cancers and surgical planning.

 

  • Level 1: A is sub mental & B is sub mandibualr
  • Level 2: Upper jugular group → from skull base to hyoid (around upper third of jugular vein, spinal accessory nodes). IIA located anterior to the SPINAL ACCESSORY NERVE and IIB located posterior to it.
  • Level 3: Middle jugular group → from hyoid to cricoid.
  • Level 4: Lower jugular group → from cricoid to clavicle.
  • Level 5: Posterior triangle group → from skull base to clavicle, posterior to sternocleidomastoid, anterior to trapezius.
  • Level 6: Central compartment → from hyoid to suprasternal notch, between carotid sheaths (includes prelaryngeal, pretracheal, paratracheal nodes).

 

Thus, the pairing “Level 5: Cricoid to suprasternal notch” is wrong — that corresponds more to Level 4/6, not Level 5.

choices.text: Lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra
Blocking this point leads to weakness of sternocleidomastoid
Landmark in the neck where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle
Formed by the C5 and C6 nerve roots, and the cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus

questions.text: All of the following are true about the marked point except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blocking this point leads to weakness of sternocleidomastoid

 

Blocking Erb's point does not cause weakness of the sternocleidomastoid muscle, as the sternocleidomastoid is mainly supplied by the spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI), which is not blocked at this point.

The marked point in the image is Erb's point (nerve point of the neck), where several cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus emerge.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra: True. Erb's point lies in front of the transverse process of the sixth cervical vertebra.

 

Option C. Landmark in the neck where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle: True. This is a landmark where the spinal accessory nerve emerges into the posterior triangle.

 

Option D. Formed by the C5 and C6 nerve roots, and the cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus: True. Erb's point is formed by the convergence of C5 and C6 nerve roots and cutaneous branches of the cervical plexus (lesser occipital, great auricular, transverse cervical, and supraclavicular nerves).

choices.text: Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection.
Oblique sinus lies behind left atrium
Transverse sinus lies behind ascending aorta
Oblique sinus allows a surgeon to ligate the pulmonary vessels

questions.text: Which of the following is accurate regarding pericardial sinuses?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Oblique sinus allows a surgeon to ligate the pulmonary vessels 

 

It is the transverse sinus, not the oblique, that is surgically important for ligating great vessels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection: Transverse sinus is between arterial and venous pericardial reflection

 

Option C. Transverse sinus lies anterior to SVC: Correct. It lies anterior to SVC and posterior to aorta and pulmonary trunk, not strictly "behind the aorta."

questions.text: As a medical officer in an occupational health program, you encounter an employee with hearing loss. You are suspicious that he is faking it to claim compensation. Which of the following tests is least useful in this scenario?
The persistence of ADHD in childhood, increases the risk of development of which of the following in adolescence?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conduct disorder 

 

Children with ADHD, especially those with persistent symptoms into adolescence, are at increased risk of developing disruptive behavior disorders, most importantly conduct disorder. Conduct disorder is characterized by aggression toward people and animals, destruction of property, deceitfulness, theft, and serious violation of rules. This condition in adolescence can progress to antisocial personality disorder in adulthood if untreated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Selective mutism: This is an anxiety disorder in which a child consistently fails to speak in specific situations (eg, at school) despite speaking normally elsewhere. It usually presents in early childhood, not as a complication of persistent ADHD.

 

Option C. Binge eating disorder: While impulsivity in ADHD may predispose to overeating in some, binge eating disorder is not a recognized common progression from childhood ADHD into adolescence.

 

Option D. Separation anxiety disorder: Typically seen in younger children (school age) who have excessive anxiety about being separated from attachment figures. It is not strongly linked to ADHD persistence into adolescence.

He has visited the emergency department several times before due to food and skin allergies. The patient is unconscious on arrival. Examination shows excessive accessory respiratory muscle use and edematous swelling of the face, lips, and tongue. There is also scattered urticaria over the upper body. The incisions made during this procedure will most likely pass through which of the following structures?

questions.text: Scientists studying the kidney's response to hypoperfusion apply a clip to a pig's right renal artery that reduces blood flow to the kidney by about 7 %. After 6 months, they perform a right nephrectomy and examine the glomeruli and tubules microscopically. Which of the following cell types would be most likely to undergo hyperplasia as a result of the clip placement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole

 

  • These are juxtaglomerular cells that hyperplasia under chronic low perfusion due to increased renin secretion.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cuboidal epithelial cells of the proximal tubules: No hyperplasia here.

 

Option B. Endothelial cells of the efferent arteriole: Not involved.

 

Option C. Intraglomerular mesangial cells: Can proliferate in GN, not in hypoperfusion.

I need to keep running so I don't get any fatter than l already am." The patient also reports difficulty concentrating in class, depressed mood, constipation, and abdominal bloating. Her appetite is normal, but she admits to occasionally forcing herself to vomit to prevent weight gain. Physical examination is significant for dry skin, parotid swelling, pharyngeal erythema, and hypoactive bowel sounds. Temperature is 36.2 C(97.2 F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, pulse is 62/min, and respirations are 16/min. BMI is 17.5 kg/m . Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to polyuria and nocturia. Her temperature is 36.7° C (98 F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min. The patient's mucous membranes appear dry. Her urine output and osmolality remain unchanged with water deprivation for several hours, but after administration of desmopressin, urine output decreases and urine osmolality increases. Renal clearance of which of the following substances would decrease the most after this patient's injection?
Which of the following is the safety muscle of larynx?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

The safety muscle of the larynx is the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle, which is responsible for abducting (opening) the vocal cords and thus maintaining a patent airway. In the image, the region labeled "C" corresponds to the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

 

  • This muscle is crucial as its bilateral paralysis can lead to life-threatening airway obstruction. It is termed the "safety muscle" of the larynx for this reason.

 

Other Options:

choices.text: Failed descent of a pharyngeal pouch structure
Failed neural crest migration into a pharyngeal arch
Incomplete obliteration of a pharyngeal groove

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a painful mass in the neck. The parents noticed a small area of nontender swelling in the neck a month ago. Over the last few days, it has enlarged and become painful, and the patient has a fever. Examination shows a mobile, tender, fluctuant, and warm mass approximately 2 cm in diameter that is located at the right mandibular angle. There is purulent drainage from the skin surface just anterior to the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. This patient's clinical findings are most likely due to which of the following embryologic processes?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Incomplete obliteration of a pharyngeal groove

questions.text: Which muscle is physically in the back but functionally in the thorax?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Levator costae

 

The levator costarum (levator costae) muscles are small, paired muscles located in the back, arising from the transverse processes of vertebrae and inserting onto the ribs below.

 

  • Anatomical position: They are in the back (dorsal region).
  • Functional role: They elevate the ribs during inspiration, thereby assisting the thoracic cage in respiration.
  • Hence, though physically present in the back, they are functionally muscles of the thorax.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rhomboid:

 

  • Located in the back.
  • Function: retract and stabilize the scapula.
  • Not functionally related to thorax.

 

Option B. Latissimus dorsi:

 

  • Large back muscle.
  • Function: adduction, extension, medial rotation of humerus.
  • Not related to respiration.

 

Option C. Trapezius:

 

  • Large superficial back muscle.
  • Function: elevates, retracts, rotates scapula.
  • Not involved in thoracic function.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management?
Which of the following nerves are connected by Galen’s Anastmosis?

A 17-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her parents for evaluation following the accidental drowning of her younger sister a week ago. The patient, her sister, and 2 friends had gone swimming in the ocean. When the sister became submerged, the patient attempted to rescue her but was overpowered by strong rip currents and was forced to return to shore. The mother is concerned that her daughter seems to be unaware of her sister's death and believes she is "in denial." The patient was unable to answer questions from the police about the drowning and reports she cannot remember any details of what happened that day. On mental status examination, the patient is alert and fully oriented. She becomes upset and confused when the incident is discussed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a extrinsic laryngeal membrane?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cricothyroid

 

The extrinsic laryngeal membranes and ligaments are those that connect the larynx to structures outside of it (like hyoid bone, epiglottis, or trachea).

 

  • These include:
    • Thyrohyoid membrane → between thyroid cartilage and hyoid bone
    • Hyoepiglottic ligament → between hyoid bone and epiglottis
    • Cricotracheal ligament → between cricoid cartilage and first tracheal ring

 

The “cricothyroid” given in the options is intrinsic to the larynx. The membrane in this region is the cricothyroid membrane (cricothyroid ligament), which is part of the intrinsic framework and forms the site for emergency cricothyrotomy.

 

Thus, Cricothyroid is not classified as an extrinsic laryngeal membrane.

On examination, there is no redness around the ear, but gentle traction of the pinna elicits pain. She is unaware of exactly when this began but says the patient had a mild upper respiratory tract infection several weeks ago. The mother also remarks that the boy's urine has been excessively foamy recently.  Which of the following secondary changes is most likely in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Increased liver lipoprotein synthesis

questions.text: Identify the incorrect pair of branch and parent nerve:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Infratrochlear-Maxillary Nerve

 

  • The infratrochlear nerve is actually a branch of the nasociliary nerve, which itself is a branch of the ophthalmic division (V1) of trigeminal nerve.
  • The option incorrectly pairs infratrochlear with the maxillary nerve (V2), which has no role in this branch.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supraorbital – Frontal Nerve: Correct. The frontal nerve (V1) divides into supraorbital and supratrochlear nerves.

 

Option B. Anterior ethmoidal – Nasociliary Nerve: Correct. The nasociliary nerve (V1) gives off anterior and posterior ethmoidal nerves.

 

Option D. Ciliary – Nasociliary Nerve: Correct. Long ciliary nerves are branches of the nasociliary nerve (V1). Short ciliary nerves arise from the ciliary ganglion (parasympathetic + sympathetic + sensory roots, including nasociliary).

questions.text: Identify the fracture in the given diagram.

A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) False negative

 

  • This patient initially had labyrinthine fistula due to acute otitis media → hence positive fistula test (vertigo/nystagmus on pressure over tragus or Siegel’s speculum).
  • With progression and worsening hearing loss, the labyrinth has likely become destroyed/non-functional.

 

Now regarding Rinne’s test:

 

  • In sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), air conduction (AC) is still better than bone conduction (BC), so Rinne remains positive.
  • But in severe–profound SNHL, the patient may not perceive sound via air conduction at all, but may feel it by bone conduction (due to skull vibrations being sensed by the opposite ear).
  • This makes Rinne appear negative (BC > AC) even though the pathology is sensorineural, not conductive.
  • This phenomenon is called a false negative Rinne test.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. True positive: Correct in conductive hearing loss (AC > BC on affected side). Not expected here.

 

Option B. True negative: Would be seen in real conductive hearing loss. Not the case here since pathology is sensorineural.

 

Option C. False positive: Occurs when bone conduction vibrations are picked up by the opposite normal ear (crossover), falsely suggesting a positive Rinne. This is different from our case.

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of a neck lump. Serum TSH level is normal. Fine-needle aspiration biopsy reveals papillary thyroid cancer. A total thyroidectomy is performed. During an attempt to ligate the inferior thyroid artery, a nervous structure in close proximity is inadvertently damaged. Which of the following was most likely injured during the surgery?
Which of the following is enclosed in the investing layer of deep cervical fascia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sternocleidomastoid

 

The investing layer of deep cervical fascia is the most superficial layer of the deep cervical fascia.

 

  • It splits to enclose sternocleidomastoid (SCM) and trapezius muscles.
  • It also forms the roof of the posterior triangle of the neck.
  • It attaches superiorly to the mandible and skull base, inferiorly to clavicle and sternum.

 

Thus, sternocleidomastoid is enclosed in this layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Esophagus: Enclosed by pretracheal fascia (visceral part), not by investing fascia.

 

Option C. Scalenus anterior: Covered by prevertebral fascia, not by investing fascia.

 

Option D. Nodes of Rouvier: These are retropharyngeal lymph nodes, lying in the retropharyngeal space, not within the investing fascia.

Disrupted ossicular chain and disrupted tympanic membrane

A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of acute chest pain. Her blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 42/min. An ECG reveals ST-segment elevation in the inferior leads. The appropriate therapy is initiated, including a medication to treat her bradycardia. After initial treatment, her blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and pulse is 76/min. However, she now complains of severe right-sided eye pain. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this patient's eye pain?
Which of the following has a poor prognosis with exposure and response prevention in OCD?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hoarding

 

Exposure and response prevention (ERP) is a highly effective cognitive-behavioral therapy for obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). However, patients with hoarding subtype of OCD respond poorly to ERP compared to other subtypes. Hoarding involves persistent difficulty discarding possessions regardless of value, leading to significant distress and functional impairment. It is often ego-syntonic (feels natural to the patient), resistant to change, and associated with poor treatment adherence and outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pathological doubt: Patients have recurrent doubts (eg, “Did I lock the door?”). ERP is effective as patients can be exposed to the anxiety-provoking situation and prevented from checking repeatedly, leading to improvement.

 

Option B. Magical thinking: Patients believe that certain thoughts or rituals prevent harmful events (eg, “If I count to 7, my mother will not die”). ERP works reasonably well here by challenging the compulsion and showing that feared outcomes do not occur.

 

Option D. Contamination obsession: This is one of the most common OCD presentations (eg, fear of dirt, germs). ERP has good efficacy by exposing patients to contamination triggers and preventing washing or cleaning rituals.

A 41-year-old woman with a long history of menorrhagia comes to the physician due to a low hemoglobin level identified on routine laboratory evaluation. She is diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia and started on oral ferrous sulfate. Which of the following cells secrete a substance that controls iron storage and release by other cells involved in iron homeostasis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hepatic parenchymal cells

 

  • Hepatic parenchymal cells (hepatocytes) secrete hepcidin, a key hormone that regulates systemic iron homeostasis.
  • Hepcidin controls iron storage and release by binding to ferroportin on enterocytes (intestinal cells), macrophages, and hepatocytes, causing its internalization and degradation.
  • Therefore, hepatic parenchymal cells are responsible for secreting the iron-regulating hormone hepcidin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biliary lining cells: Not involved in iron regulation.

 

Option B. Bone marrow macrophages: Involved in iron recycling but do not secrete hepcidin.

 

Option C. Enterocytes: Absorb iron but do not regulate iron homeostasis by hormone secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatocytes (hepatic parenchymal cells) secrete hepcidin, a key hormone regulating iron homeostasis. Hepcidin controls iron storage and release by binding to ferroportin on enterocytes, macrophages, and hepatocytes to regulate iron absorption and recycling. Other options are not involved in secreting the substance that controls iron storage and release.

A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician with jaundice and pallor. He was adopted and his family history is unknown. Laboratory studies show anemia, reticulocytosis, and increased indirect bilirubin. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is most likely to have which of the following additional findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increased MCHC

 

  • The patient's presentation of anemia, reticulocytosis, increased indirect bilirubin, and the peripheral smear showing spherocytes suggests hereditary spherocytosis.
  • In hereditary spherocytosis, red blood cells are sphere-shaped and have increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC) due to decrease in cell surface area.
  • Additional findings typically include:
    • Decreased haptoglobin (not increased) due to hemolysis.
    • Increased lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) (not decreased) from cell breakdown.
    • Negative Coombs test because it's a hereditary membrane defect, not autoimmune hemolysis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman states that over the last 6 months she has felt constantly nervous. She adds that sometimes “I feel like my heart is going to burst.” She also notes that her heart skips a beat from time to time, and that she is having trouble sleeping. She denies feeling depressed. The patient denies flight of ideas, pressured speech, increased goal-directed activity, hallucinations, or delusions. The patient also complains of increased bowel movements and weight loss, along with significant weakness when she attempts to climb stairs or lift heavy items. The patient’s vital signs are: temperature 37.8°C (100.1°F), pulse 102/min, blood pressure 124/85 mm Hg, and respiratory rate 18/min. What would be the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methimazole

 

This patient presents with anxiety-like symptoms (nervousness, palpitations, insomnia), but the presence of systemic features such as weight loss despite increased bowel movements, proximal muscle weakness, tachycardia, and low-grade fever strongly suggest hyperthyroidism rather than a primary psychiatric disorder. Methimazole is an antithyroid drug that inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and is the first-line medical treatment for hyperthyroidism (except during the first trimester of pregnancy, where propylthiouracil is used). Treating the underlying thyroid disorder will resolve both the physical and psychiatric manifestations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alprazolam: This benzodiazepine is used for acute anxiety relief but would not address the underlying cause here. Giving alprazolam might temporarily relieve nervousness but would miss the diagnosis of hyperthyroidism, leading to ongoing systemic harm.

 

Option B. Investigation of surreptitious laxative abuse: Laxative abuse can cause weight loss, diarrhea, and electrolyte abnormalities, but it would not explain palpitations, tachycardia, and proximal muscle weakness. The systemic signs point to hyperthyroidism instead.

 

Option D. Sertraline: Sertraline is an SSRI used for generalized anxiety disorder and depression. It would not treat the systemic cause of the patient’s symptoms. In fact, misdiagnosing this as a primary anxiety disorder would delay appropriate treatment for hyperthyroidism.

At which of the following levels does an inverted Supinator jerk indicate a lesion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) C5, C6

 

The supinator jerk (brachioradialis reflex) is elicited by tapping the tendon of the brachioradialis muscle near the wrist.

 

  • Normal response → flexion & supination of forearm.
  • This reflex tests the C5–C6 spinal segments, mainly radial nerve function.

 

An inverted supinator jerk means:

 

  • When the reflex is elicited, instead of forearm flexion/supination, there is finger flexion due to overactivity of finger flexors.
  • This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion at C5–C6, with sparing of lower segments (C7–T1).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. C6, C7:

 

  • Associated more with triceps reflex.
  • Not responsible for inverted supinator jerk.

 

Option C. L5, S1:

 

  • Involved in ankle jerk reflex.
  • Not related to supinator reflex.

 

Option D. L4, S1:

 

  • Combination not relevant; knee jerk is L3–L4, ankle jerk L5–S1.

questions.text: Identify the nerve injured:
What is the likely genetic abnormality in the following patient?
All of the following form boundaries of quadrangular space except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Supraspinatus

 

The quadrangular space is an important anatomical space in the posterior shoulder region that allows passage of the axillary nerve and posterior circumflex humeral artery.

 

Its boundaries are:

 

  • Superior: Teres minor
  • Inferior: Teres major
  • Medial: Long head of triceps
  • Lateral: Surgical neck of humerus

 

 

Supraspinatus does not take part in forming this space. It is located superiorly in the supraspinous fossa and is related to the suprascapular notch, not the quadrangular space.

A college student complains that she is unable to sleep properly. This is making it hard for her to concentrate on her studies and has led to a fall in her grades. She lies on her bed for at least 8-9 hours but has difficulty falling asleep. She has no history of drug abuse. For how many months should the symptoms persist before you diagnose her with insomnia disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3 months 

 

Insomnia disorder is characterized by difficulty initiating or maintaining sleep or early morning awakening with inability to return to sleep, despite adequate opportunity for rest. The disturbance must cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or academic functioning.

 

According to DSM-5 diagnostic criteria, for a diagnosis of insomnia disorder, the sleep difficulty must occur:

 

  • At least 3 nights per week, and
  • Persist for at least 3 months

 

In this case, the student has trouble falling asleep, leading to poor concentration and academic decline, and the symptoms have persisted for a sufficient period to warrant a diagnosis if they last ≥3 months.

questions.text: A patient came from a factory with a chemical injury to the eye a few hours back. Which is the first step in the management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Copious irrigation of eyes

 

In a patient with chemical injury to the eye, the first and most critical step is immediate and copious irrigation of the affected eye — even before taking history or assessing vision.

 

The goal is to remove or dilute the chemical agent as quickly as possible to prevent further penetration and damage to ocular tissues.

 

Why Irrigation Is the First Step:

 

  • Every second counts — the severity of ocular injury depends on contact time of the chemical with the cornea and conjunctiva.
  • Early and thorough irrigation can dramatically reduce long-term damage like corneal scarring, symblepharon, or vision loss.
  • Irrigation should continue until the ocular surface pH normalizes (checked with litmus paper or pH strips).

 

Ideal method:

 

  • Use normal saline, Ringer’s lactate, or even clean tap water if nothing else is available.
  • Eyelids should be everted to wash out trapped particles.
  • Irrigation is continued for at least 30 minutes or until pH = 7.0–7.4.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IOP measurement: Inappropriate as an initial step. Measuring intraocular pressure is delayed until after irrigation and stabilization, as early tonometry may worsen corneal damage or contamination.

 

Option B. Visual acuity: Assessment of visual acuity is important but not before irrigation. Immediate vision testing wastes critical time when chemical damage is ongoing.

 

Option D. Take history: History (chemical type, exposure duration) is important after irrigation. During the acute stage, the focus is on neutralizing and flushing the chemical.

questions.text: A child presents with proptosis, pain and Loss of vision. O/E the following picture is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Orbital cellulitis

 

Orbital cellulitis is a severe infection involving the tissues behind the orbital septum, often presenting with proptosis (bulging of the eye), pain, decreased vision, and restricted or painful eye movements. The key differentiating features in this case are proptosis and loss of vision, which are characteristic of orbital cellulitis and not usually seen in preseptal cellulitis. The condition requires urgent medical treatment to prevent complications, including permanent vision loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Stye: A stye is a localized infection of an eyelash follicle or gland, which would present as a painful, swollen area on the eyelid margin but typically does not cause proptosis or affect vision.

 

Option C. Preseptal cellulitis: This infection involves the eyelid and periocular tissue anterior to the orbital septum. It causes swelling and redness of the eyelid but does not involve proptosis, vision loss, or pain with eye movements, which helps distinguish it from orbital cellulitis.

 

Option D. Blepharitis: Blepharitis is an inflammation of the eyelid margins, often associated with redness, irritation, and crusting at the lash line. It does not cause proptosis, pain, or vision loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of proptosis, pain, and vision loss in a child suggests orbital cellulitis, a serious condition that requires immediate medical intervention.

 

Note:

questions.text: Match the following treatment approaches with their primary use:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A-4, B-1, C-2, D-3

 

A. Motivational interviewing - 4. Enhancing motivation for change: Motivational interviewing is a client-centered counseling approach designed to help individuals explore and resolve ambivalence, thereby enhancing their motivation to change behaviors such as substance use.

 

B. Cognitive-behavioral therapy - 1. Relapse prevention: CBT focuses on identifying and changing negative thought patterns and behaviors. In substance use disorders, it is used to teach coping strategies to help prevent relapse.

 

C. 12-step programs - 2. Peer support and spirituality-based recovery: 12-step programs, such as Alcoholics Anonymous, are based on peer support, mutual aid, and often include a spiritual component to support recovery.

 

D. Contingency management - 3. Reinforcing abstinence with tangible rewards: Contingency management involves providing incentives, such as vouchers or other rewards, for positive behaviors like abstinence from drug use.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 280-284.

questions.text: A recurrent bilateral conjunctivitis occurring with the onset of hot weather in young boys with symptoms of burning, itching, and lacrimation with large, flat- topped cobblestone papillae, raised areas in the palpebral conjunctiva is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vernal keratoconjunctivitis

 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is an allergic eye condition primarily affecting young boys and is often exacerbated by hot weather. VKC is characterized by recurrent, bilateral conjunctivitis with symptoms of burning, itching, lacrimation, and the presence of large, flat-topped "cobblestone" papillae on the palpebral conjunctiva.

 

 

Key features include:

 

  • Seasonal recurrence: Often worsens in warm weather or spring, hence the term "vernal."
  • Symptoms: Intense itching, burning, and excessive tearing (lacrimation).
  • Cobblestone papillae: Large, flat-topped papillae are highly characteristic of VKC and can be found in the upper tarsal conjunctiva.

 

Treatment options include:

 

  • Antihistamines and mast cell stabilizers like olopatadine, sodium cromoglycate, epinastine, alcaftadine, and pipotastine to manage allergic symptoms.
  • Topical steroids for acute exacerbations: Dexamethasone, betamethasone, and prednisolone (stronger steroids) are effective but can increase intraocular pressure (IOP).
  • Milder topical steroids for safer long-term use without IOP rise: Fluorometholone and loteprednol.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trachoma: Trachoma is a chronic, slowly progressing conjunctivitis that does not present with acute symptoms like burning and itching or large cobblestone papillae. It primarily causes gradual scarring over years, eventually leading to complications like entropion and trichiasis.

 

Option B. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: This is a hypersensitivity reaction typically associated with Mycobacterium tuberculosis and does not have the characteristic cobblestone papillae or seasonal pattern seen in VKC.

 

Option C. Mucopurulent conjunctivitis: This type of conjunctivitis is generally caused by bacterial infection and presents with purulent discharge rather than the allergic symptoms and papillae characteristic of VKC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is a recurrent, bilateral conjunctivitis affecting young boys in hot weather, characterized by cobblestone papillae, itching, burning, and lacrimation, and managed with antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers, and topical steroids.

questions.text: Number of layers in neurosensory retina is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 9

 

The neurosensory retina comprises 9 layers derived from the inner layer of the optic cup during embryological development. These layers are responsible for visual signal processing and transmission. The retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) forms the 10th layer but is not part of the neurosensory retina; it develops from the outer layer of the optic cup.

 

Layers of the Neurosensory Retina:

 

  1. Inner limiting membrane
  2. Nerve fiber layer
  3. Ganglion cell layer
  4. Inner plexiform layer
  5. Inner nuclear layer
  6. Outer plexiform layer
  7. Outer nuclear layer
  8. External limiting membrane
  9. Photoreceptor layer

 

The 10th layer, the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE), lies external to the photoreceptor layer and is not part of the neurosensory retina.

 

Embryological Insight:

 

  • The retina develops from the optic vesicle, which invaginates to form the optic cup.
  • The inner layer of the optic cup forms the 9 layers of the neurosensory retina.
  • The outer layer of the optic cup forms the RPE.
  • During retinal detachment, the neurosensory retina separates from the RPE, highlighting the embryological division between these two layers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The neurosensory retina has 9 layers, while the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) forms the 10th layer, completing the retina’s structure.

questions.text: Retro-bulbar optic neuritis is characterized by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Impaired direct light reflex in the affected eye

 

Retro-bulbar optic neuritis refers to inflammation of the optic nerve behind the eyeball, sparing the optic disc. Key features include:

 

  • Impaired direct light reflex: In the affected eye, the optic nerve damage disrupts the afferent pathway, resulting in a reduced or absent direct light reflex.
  • Normal appearance of the optic disc: Unlike optic neuritis involving the disc (papillitis), the optic disc appears normal on fundoscopy because the inflammation is retro-bulbar.
  • Reduced visual acuity: The patient experiences sudden vision loss in the affected eye despite a normal-looking optic disc.
  • Relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD): This is often observed and reflects optic nerve dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Retro-bulbar optic neuritis is characterized by impaired direct light reflex due to damage to the afferent pathway, with a normal-looking optic disc despite significant vision loss.
