questions.text: Severe congenital ptosis with no levator function can be treated by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fascia lata sling operation

 

In severe congenital ptosis where the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) has no functional activity, the best surgical approach is the fascia lata sling operation. This involves suspending the upper eyelid to the frontalis muscle using fascia lata or a similar material. This allows the patient to use the action of the frontalis muscle to elevate the eyelid, compensating for the lack of LPS function.

 

  • Congenital ptosis with no LPS action: The key issue is the inability of the levator muscle to lift the eyelid. Sling surgery bypasses this by utilizing another muscle's function.
  • Severe ptosis (approximately 4 mm or more): Sling surgery is indicated for severe ptosis, as it provides effective elevation even when the levator function is completely absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Levator resection from skin side: Levator resection strengthens the LPS muscle by shortening it, but this is only effective when there is some residual LPS function, which is not the case here.

 

Option B. Levator resection from conjunctival side: Like the skin-side resection, this approach is used to improve LPS function when some activity is present. It is not suitable for complete LPS failure.

 

Option D. Fasanella servat operation: This procedure is performed for mild ptosis (2 mm or less), such as in Horner’s syndrome, where the LPS function is intact but reduced. It is not suitable for severe cases with no LPS action.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fascia lata sling surgery is the treatment of choice for severe congenital ptosis with no levator palpebrae superioris (LPS) function, allowing the frontalis muscle to compensate for eyelid elevation.

choices.text: An effective seizure should last for at least 2 minutes
ECT treatments are usually administered twice or thrice weekly, non consecutively
﻿﻿﻿Maximum number of times ECT can be given in a patient is 6

questions.text: You are observing electroconvulsive therapy being administered to a psychiatric patient. Which of the following statements is true regarding the procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ECT treatments are usually administered twice or thrice weekly, non consecutively

 

Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a controlled procedure used for severe psychiatric conditions such as major depressive disorder with suicidality, catatonia, and treatment-resistant psychosis. The treatment course and frequency are standardized to ensure both safety and therapeutic efficacy.

 

True statement:

 

  • ECT is generally administered 2–3 times per week on non-consecutive days (e.g., Monday–Wednesday–Friday schedule).
  • A typical acute course consists of 6–12 sessions, though some patients (especially with catatonia or chronic depression) may require more.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. An effective seizure should last for at least 2 minutes: False.
An adequate ECT-induced seizure typically lasts 20–50 seconds on EEG or clinically at least 15 seconds. A seizure longer than 2 minutes is prolonged and may require medical intervention (e.g., benzodiazepine termination).

 

Option C. Maximum number of times ECT can be given in a patient is 6: False. There is no fixed upper limit for ECT treatments. While 6–12 sessions are common in an acute series, additional maintenance ECT can be given weekly or monthly for relapse prevention in recurrent illness.

questions.text: A young child suffering from fever and sore throat began to complain of lacrimation. On examination, follicles were found in the lower palpebral conjunctiva with tender preauricular lymph nodes. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenoviral conjunctivitis

 

The presentation of fever, sore throat, lacrimation, follicles on the lower palpebral conjunctiva, and tender preauricular lymph nodes strongly suggests adenoviral conjunctivitis, specifically a form known as pharyngoconjunctival fever (PCF). PCF is commonly caused by adenovirus, which affects both the respiratory tract and the conjunctiva.

 

Key features:

 

  • Pharyngoconjunctival fever (PCF): Characterized by a triad of pharyngitis (sore throat), conjunctivitis, and fever.
  • Follicular reaction in the conjunctiva and tender preauricular lymphadenopathy are hallmark signs of adenoviral conjunctivitis.
  • PCF often occurs in children and can be associated with outbreaks in close-contact settings like schools or camps.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trachoma: Trachoma can cause follicles in the conjunctiva but is typically chronic and not associated with acute symptoms like fever and sore throat.

 

Option B. Staphylococcal conjunctivitis: This bacterial conjunctivitis presents with purulent discharge rather than follicles and is not associated with systemic symptoms like fever and sore throat.

 

Option D. Phlyctenular conjunctivitis: This condition is associated with hypersensitivity to bacterial antigens, particularly from Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and usually does not present with fever, sore throat, or follicular conjunctivitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pharyngoconjunctival fever, caused by adenovirus, presents with fever, sore throat, follicular conjunctivitis, and tender preauricular lymph nodes, making adenoviral conjunctivitis the most probable diagnosis.

choices.text: Orthostatic hypotension, hypothermia, and skin dryness
Salivary gland hypertrophy, dental enamel erosion, and scars on the knuckles
Scarring on the flexor surface of the wrist

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the ED with a heart rate of 37/min. The patient’s mother insisted that the girl seek medical attention because she “always seems so tired.” The patient saw a psychotherapist briefly last year for “low self-esteem.” Otherwise, she has no significant psychiatric history. The patient lives with her parents and is exceptionally close with her mother. She is a grade -A student at the exclusive private high school. Her temperature is 36.4°C (97.5°F),blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, and respiratory rate is 17/min. Her body mass index is 17kg/m2. What are the patient’s physical examination and laboratory studies likely to show?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Orthostatic hypotension, hypothermia, and skin dryness

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic patient reports experiencing fluctuating blurred vision over the past few weeks. He notes that his blood sugar levels have been inconsistent due to a recent illness. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his fluctuating myopia?
The best treatment for amblyopia is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Occlusion

 

The most effective treatment for amblyopia (also known as lazy eye) is occlusion therapy, commonly referred to as patching. This involves covering the stronger (normal) eye to force the amblyopic (weaker) eye to work harder, thereby stimulating visual development in the lazy eye. Patching is most effective in children up to around 7 years of age, as the visual system is still plastic and responsive to treatment at this age.

 

Additional Treatment Methods for Amblyopia:

 

  • Penalization: In cases where patching is not tolerated by the child, atropine drops can be used in the good eye. Atropine blurs the vision in the normal eye, encouraging the lazy eye to work more. This method is also effective and is referred to as "penalization."
  • Orthoptic exercises: These are sometimes used as supplementary therapy but are not the primary treatment for amblyopia.
  • Treatment window: Treatment is most effective in early childhood (typically under 7 years), as amblyopia becomes harder to treat after the age of 10 due to reduced neural plasticity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Surgery: Surgery does not directly treat amblyopia. While surgery may correct strabismus (misalignment of the eyes) associated with amblyopia, it does not improve vision in the amblyopic eye.

 

Option D. Best treated after age 10 years: Amblyopia is ideally treated before age 10, as the success rate decreases significantly as the child grows older and the visual system becomes less adaptable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occlusion therapy (patching of the good eye) is the most effective treatment for amblyopia in young children, forcing the amblyopic eye to improve through increased usage. Penalization with atropine drops can also be used if patching is not tolerated.

questions.text: As part of a psychiatric evaluation, you ask the patient about what he would do if he suddenly sees a house on fire. What is being assessed here?
questions.solution:
Ans. ﻿﻿﻿B) Test judgment 

 

In a psychiatric interview, when a patient is asked “What would you do if you saw a house on fire?”, the goal is to assess judgment, specifically test judgment — the patient’s ability to understand a hypothetical social situation and make a reasoned, safe, and socially appropriate decision.

 

Test judgment evaluates intellectual reasoning in response to an imagined or hypothetical scenario, rather than actual real-life behavior.
A normal response would be: “Call the fire department,” or “Try to help while keeping myself safe.”


An impaired response might be unrealistic, impulsive, or dangerous (e.g., “I’d run inside to save my TV.”).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Social judgment: Refers to how a person behaves or makes decisions in real-life social situations (e.g., how they interact with others, handle conflicts, or manage money). It’s usually assessed by reviewing past actions or real incidents, not by hypothetical questions.

 

Option C. Response judgment: This term is not commonly used in psychiatric terminology; sometimes used to describe immediate decision-making under pressure, but not part of standard mental status examination (MSE).

 

Option D. Pyromaniac tendency: Refers to pathological fire-setting behavior driven by an impulse or fascination with fire.

choices.text: FEV1 low, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low
FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC high
FEV1 high, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low
FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC low

questions.text: A 38-year-old man comes to the OPD with reports of dyspnea on exertion and decreased exercise tolerance. His medical history is unremarkable, and he has no history of childhood asthma or cough. The patient has gained almost 30kg over the past 4 years due to a sedentary lifestyle. He currently has a BMI of 41 kg/m2. His respiratory rate is 22/min and pulse oximetry is 93% on room air at rest. Physical examination is notable for central obesity. Lungs are clear on auscultation bilaterally. Which of the following changes are most likely to be seen on pulmonary function testing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) FEV1 low, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low 

 

Obesity causes a restrictive pattern in PFTs with decreased FEV1, FVC, and total lung capacity (TLC), while residual volume (RV) typically remains normal.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC high: Typical of obstructive lung disease, not obesity-related restriction.

 

Option C. FEV1 high, FVC low, RV normal, TLC low: An uncommon pattern; FEV1 usually decreases alongside FVC in restriction.

 

Option D. FEV1 low, FVC low, RV high, TLC low: Increased RV is unusual in pure restrictive conditions like obesity.

questions.text: A 35 year old male Anand Jain on slit lamp shows keratic precipitates & aqueous flare in his right eye. No synechiae but a complicated cataract is seen. The probable diagnosis would be:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Heterochromic iridocyclitis of Fuch’s

 

Fuchs’ heterochromic iridocyclitis (FHI) is a chronic, low-grade, non-granulomatous uveitis that typically presents unilaterally in young or middle-aged adults.

 

Key features seen in this case:

 

  • Keratic precipitates: Fine, stellate, diffusely scattered over the endothelium.
  • Aqueous flare present but no posterior synechiae — this absence is characteristic.
  • Complicated cataract (usually posterior subcapsular) is a common complication.
  • Often, heterochromia (difference in iris colour between eyes) may be noted due to iris atrophy, though it can be subtle in dark irides.

 

Hence, the findings point toward Fuchs’ hetero-chromic iridocyclitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intermediate uveitis: Inflammation mainly in the vitreous and peripheral retina (pars plana) — presents with floaters, snowballs, and snow banking, not primarily with KPs and anterior chamber flare.

 

Option B. Heerfordt’s syndrome: A manifestation of sarcoidosis with parotid enlargement, facial nerve palsy, uveitis, and fever. It’s systemic and not limited to the eye with these slit-lamp findings.

 

Option C. Subacute iridocyclitis: Refers to anterior uveitis of intermediate duration (between acute and chronic). Usually has pain, redness, synechiae formation, and more intense inflammation — unlike the mild, quiet anterior chamber in Fuchs’.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with oral carcinoma was referred to the ENT department for evaluation. While examining the oral cavity, the consultant asked you to examine the ENT surgeon's graveyard to check for any induration or ulcers. What is the area being referred to here?

A male patient 30 years old Gobind Gupta with visual acuity of 6/6 in both eyes. Twelve hours ago he presented with drop of vision of the left eye. On examination, visual acuity was 6/6 in the right eye and 6/60 in the left eye. Fundus examination showed blurred edges of the left optic disc. The most probable diagnosis is:

choices.text: Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis
Vasoconstriction of small vessels in the cochlea

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of hypertension and chronic heart failure is prescribed furosemide. He later develops hearing impairment. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of his hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oedema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis

 

Furosemide is a loop diuretic and is known for its ototoxicity, especially when used chronically or in high doses. It disrupts the function of the stria vascularis, a structure in the cochlea responsible for the production of endolymph. The mechanism involves the development of edema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis, impairing the ion gradient required for normal cochlear function, particularly the potassium differential. This results in a disruption of the endocochlear potential and leads to hearing impairment.

 

Other loop diuretics, such as bumetanide and ethacrynic acid, are also associated with ototoxicity, especially when administered intravenously or with other ototoxic agents.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Damage to the cochlear nerve: Direct damage to the cochlear nerve is not a known mechanism of furosemide-induced ototoxicity. Cochlear nerve damage is more commonly associated with conditions such as acoustic neuroma or other neurotoxic agents.

 

Option C. Vasoconstriction of small vessels in the cochlea: While ischemia can contribute to hearing loss in certain conditions, it is not the primary mechanism of ototoxicity with furosemide. Furosemide acts on the stria vascularis rather than affecting cochlear blood vessels directly.

 

Option D. Disruption of the basilar membrane: The basilar membrane plays a critical role in sound wave transmission, but furosemide does not directly disrupt this structure. Hearing loss in this case is due to ionic imbalance caused by stria vascularis dysfunction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Furosemide causes hearing loss by inducing edema and cystic changes in the stria vascularis, which impairs endolymph production and disrupts the ionic gradient necessary for normal cochlear function.

questions.text: All of the following are minor diagnostic criteria for allergic fungal sinusitis except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Positive fungal stain

 

In the diagnosis of allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS), the criteria are classified into major and minor categories. The distinction between fungal stain and culture is essential for differentiating the major and minor criteria.

 

  • Positive fungal stain is a major diagnostic criterion because it provides immediate confirmation of fungal elements in the mucin, typically through methods like potassium hydroxide (KOH) staining or other rapid techniques. This is crucial for a timely diagnosis.
  • Fungal culture, on the other hand, is a minor diagnostic criterion. It is used for further identification of the specific fungal species, but it takes longer to yield results (often days to weeks), making it a slower diagnostic tool compared to staining.
  • Asthma is a common comorbidity seen in patients with allergic fungal sinusitis and is considered a minor criterion.
  • Eosinophilic mucin is considered a major diagnostic criterion as it is characteristic of allergic fungal sinusitis, showing abundant eosinophils without fungal hyphae in the mucin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asthma: A minor criterion commonly seen in patients with allergic fungal sinusitis.

 

Option B. Fungal culture: Considered a minor diagnostic criterion because of the time it takes to yield results.

 

Option C. Eosinophilic mucin: This is actually a major diagnostic criterion, not a minor one.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In allergic fungal sinusitis (AFS), positive fungal stain is a major diagnostic criterion because it provides rapid confirmation of fungal involvement, while fungal culture is a minor criterion due to the delayed time for results.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with episodes of vertigo that occur when she moves her head quickly. The episodes last for a few seconds and are accompanied by nausea. Which structure in the inner ear is primarily responsible for sensing the angular movements that lead to her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cristae

 

The cristae ampullaris are the sensory structures located within the ampullae of the semicircular canals in the inner ear. They are responsible for detecting angular or rotational head movements. When the head moves, the endolymph in the semicircular canals moves relative to the cristae, causing deflection of the cupula, which triggers the sensory hair cells to transmit signals about angular acceleration to the brain.

 

  • Semicircular canals are specialized for detecting angular acceleration, and the cristae are the sensory structures that process these signals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maculae: Maculae are sensory structures located in the utricle and saccule. They are responsible for detecting linear acceleration and gravitational forces, not angular movements.

 

Option C. Organ of Corti: The organ of Corti is located in the cochlea and is responsible for hearing, not balance or movement detection.

 

Option D. Otolith organs: The otolith organs, which include the utricle and saccule, are involved in sensing linear movements and head position relative to gravity. They are not responsible for detecting angular movements.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cristae ampullaris within the semicircular canals are responsible for detecting angular or rotational head movements, distinguishing them from the maculae in the otolith organs, which detect linear acceleration.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with a known cerebral vascular anomaly and seizures presented to your OPD. She gives a two-week history of objects around her appearing to be larger than they actually were, and that she noticed deformations in objects. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician with ataxia, myoclonus, and visual problems. His parents say that he began acting strangely and having difficulty with school work several months ago. After the appropriate workup, a brain biopsy is obtained and an RNA virus containing hemagglutinin is cultured from the tissue sample. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A patient presents with vertigo associated with horizontal nystagmus. The slow component is towards the right. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right hypoactive labyrinth

 

In this scenario, the slow component of the nystagmus is directed towards the right, meaning that the right labyrinth (inner ear) is hypoactive or underperforming. Nystagmus typically has a slow phase towards the affected side and a fast phase away from the affected side. The fast phase determines the direction of the nystagmus, while the slow phase indicates the side of the pathology.

 

  • A right hypoactive labyrinth would cause slow-phase nystagmus towards the right and fast-phase nystagmus towards the left, indicating right-sided vestibular weakness or hypofunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Posterior canal BPPV: This type of BPPV does not cause horizontal nystagmus and is not typically associated with a slow-phase nystagmus towards one side.

 

Option B. Superior canal BPPV: Similarly, superior canal BPPV is not associated with horizontal nystagmus and would not cause slow-phase nystagmus to one side.

 

Option D. Left hypoactive labyrinth: This would result in the slow-phase nystagmus being directed to the left, with fast-phase nystagmus to the right, which is the opposite of what is described in the case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of vertigo with horizontal nystagmus, the slow phase of the nystagmus indicates the side of the vestibular lesion or hypofunction. The fast phase shows the direction of the nystagmus, which is the opposite of the lesion side. For example, right hypoactive labyrinth leads to slow-phase nystagmus to the right and fast-phase nystagmus to the left.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents for tympanoplasty. During the surgery, the surgeon finds that both the malleus and incus are absent. According to Wullstein's classification, which type of tympanoplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Type III

 

According to Wullstein’s classification of tympanoplasty, the types are categorized based on the extent of ossicular chain involvement and the placement of the tympanic membrane graft:

 

  • Type I: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on an intact and functioning ossicular chain.
  • Type II: The tympanic membrane graft is placed on the incus, with the malleus absent or eroded.
  • Type III: The tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent. This reconstructs the sound conduction mechanism to use the stapes as the connection to the inner ear.
  • Type IV: The tympanic membrane graft is placed over the round window to protect it when the stapes is eroded or absent.

 

In this case, with both the malleus and incus absent, the graft is directly placed on the stapes, fitting the criteria for Type III tympanoplasty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: This involves placement of the tympanic membrane graft on an intact and functioning ossicular chain, which is not applicable here as both the malleus and incus are absent.

 

Option B. Type II: This involves graft placement on the incus with the malleus absent or eroded. However, in this case, the incus is also absent, so Type II tympanoplasty does not apply.

 

Option D. Type IV: This involves covering the round window with a tympanic membrane graft when the stapes is eroded or absent, which is not the scenario here as the stapes is present and intact.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Type III tympanoplasty, the tympanic membrane graft is placed directly on the stapes head when both the malleus and incus are absent, as per Wullstein’s classification.

questions.text: A man attends three sessions per week with his psychiatrist. During each session, he begins to talk, saying whatever comes to his mind. Occasionally, the patient relates dreams that he remembers from the previous night. The psychiatrist remains silent for the majority of the session, asking only about details to clarify what the patient says. This is an example of which of the following types of therapy?

A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes, particularly during the spring and summer months. On examination, you observe the presence of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of immunologic reaction is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction

 

This case is indicative of Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic eye condition that is more common in children and young adults, particularly males. VKC often worsens in warmer seasons, such as spring and summer, due to an increased exposure to allergens. The image shows giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva, which is characteristic of VKC and is often referred to as a "cobblestone" appearance.

 

The pathogenesis of VKC primarily involves a Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction, which is an IgE-mediated response. This type of hypersensitivity involves mast cell degranulation, leading to the release of histamines and other mediators that cause itching, redness, and mucous discharge. VKC is also associated with Maxwell-Lyon Sign (ropy, mucous discharge) and Horner-Trantas Dots (white, gelatinous deposits at the limbus).

 

  • Treatment includes antihistamines, mast cell stabilizers like olopatadine, and in severe cases, steroids or immunosuppressive therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Type 2 Hypersensitivity Reaction: Incorrect. Type 2 hypersensitivity involves antibody-mediated cell destruction, which is not relevant in VKC.

 

Option C. Type 3 Hypersensitivity Reaction: Incorrect. Type 3 hypersensitivity is immune-complex mediated and not typically involved in VKC.

 

Option D. Type 4 Hypersensitivity Reaction: Incorrect. Type 4 hypersensitivity is a delayed-type response, often involved in conditions like contact dermatitis, not in VKC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is primarily a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, leading to the development of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and other symptoms, often triggered by seasonal allergens.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of chronic otitis media presents with a sudden onset of severe hearing loss. Audiometry reveals a conductive hearing loss of 54 dB. Given the levels of normal conversation, what is the patient's level of hearing loss equivalent to in everyday sounds?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal conversation

 

Hearing thresholds can be categorized based on decibel levels of everyday sounds:

 

  • Whisper: ~30 dB
  • Normal conversation: ~60 dB
  • Shouting: ~90 dB
  • Discomfort: ~120 dB

 

With a hearing loss of 54 dB, the patient would have difficulty perceiving sounds at a conversational level, as this threshold aligns with the range of normal conversation (~60 dB). This explains why the patient experiences significant hearing impairment in everyday situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Whisper: Whispering corresponds to ~30 dB. A hearing loss of 54 dB would far exceed this range, making whispers completely inaudible to the patient.

 

Option C. Shout: Shouting typically reaches ~90 dB, which is much louder than the patient’s reported hearing loss threshold of 54 dB. Shouts would still likely be heard by the patient.

 

Option D. Discomfort of the ear: Discomfort occurs at very high sound levels (~120 dB), such as from loud machinery or explosions, which is unrelated to the patient's hearing loss level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A conductive hearing loss of 54 dB corresponds to the inability to hear normal conversation (~60 dB), significantly affecting communication in everyday situations.

questions.text: Identify the lesion and its etiology:
A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has Minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Stage IIA

 

The Radkowski staging system is commonly used to stage juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), a benign but locally aggressive vascular tumor that typically affects adolescent males.

 

  • Stage I: The tumor is confined to the nasopharynx and nasal cavity.
    • Stage IA: The tumor is limited to the nasopharynx.
    • Stage IB: The tumor extends into the paranasal sinuses.
  • Stage II: The tumor extends beyond the nasopharynx and nasal cavity into adjacent areas.
    • Stage IIA: The tumor has minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa.
    • Stage IIB: The tumor completely fills the pterygopalatine fossa and may involve the infratemporal fossa.
  • Stage III: The tumor extends into the intracranial cavity.
    • Stage IIIA: Intracranial extension without invasion of the dura.
    • Stage IIIB: Intracranial extension with dural invasion.

 

In this case, the tumor is confined to the nasopharynx but has minimal extension into the pterygopalatine fossa, which corresponds to Stage IIA according to the Radkowski staging system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stage IA: This stage involves a tumor confined to the nasopharynx without extension to other areas.

 

Option B. Stage IB: This involves extension into the paranasal sinuses but not beyond.

 

Option D. Stage IIB: This would involve the tumor completely filling the pterygopalatine fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Radkowski Stage IIA of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, the tumor extends beyond the nasopharynx into the pterygopalatine fossa with minimal involvement, distinguishing it from more advanced stages where the tumor completely fills or extends further laterally.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother due to unusual nighttime behavior. The mother reports that once or twice a month over the past year she has found her daughter walking around the house between the hours of midnight and 2 AM. The mother says, "Although her eyes are open, she appears to be in a daze and doesn't respond to me. I guide her back to bed and she goes back to sleep, but I worry that she could get hurt or fall down the stairs if I'm not there." The girl has no recollection of the events. Which of the following EEG patterns is characteristic of the sleep stage associated with this behavior?
The action of inferior oblique is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Elevation, extorsion, abduction

 

The inferior oblique is an extraocular muscle responsible for specific movements of the eye. Its primary actions are:

 

  1. Elevation: It elevates the eye, moving it upward.
  2. Extorsion: It rotates the top of the eye outward, away from the nose.
  3. Abduction: It moves the eye laterally, away from the midline.

 

These actions are crucial for the coordinated movements of the eye, especially during gaze shifts. The mnemonic "superiors are intorters, so inferiors are extorters" helps to remember that inferior muscles are associated with extorsion. Additionally, obliques are abductors, while recti muscles are primarily adductors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inferior oblique muscle causes elevation, extorsion, and abduction of the eye. It is also the only extraocular muscle that does not originate from the orbital apex; instead, it arises from the medial wall of the orbit.

 

Note:

questions.text: A psychologist gives the following card to a patient and asks him to describe what he sees. Which of the following is being assessed here?

choices.text: Eighth nerve, olivary complex, cochlear nucleus, inferior colliculus, lateral lemniscus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex
Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex
Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, lateral lemniscus, olivary complex, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex
Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, lateral lemniscus, medial geniculate body, olivary complex, inferior colliculus, auditory cortex

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is undergoing a brainstem evoked response audiometry (BERA) test to evaluate her auditory pathway. Which of the following correctly lists the sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the cochlea to the auditory cortex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Eighth nerve, cochlear nucleus, olivary complex, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, medial geniculate body, auditory cortex

 

The auditory pathway is the neural pathway by which sound is transmitted from the cochlea to the auditory cortex in the brain. The correct sequence of structures is as follows:

 

  1. Eighth nerve (Cochlear nerve): Transmits auditory signals from the cochlea to the brainstem.
  2. Cochlear nucleus: The first synapse in the auditory pathway, located in the brainstem.
  3. Olivary complex (specifically the superior olivary complex): Processes binaural cues for sound localization.
  4. Lateral lemniscus: A tract that transmits auditory signals further up the brainstem.
  5. Inferior colliculus: Integrates and processes auditory information in the midbrain.
  6. Medial geniculate body: A relay center in the thalamus that projects to the auditory cortex.
  7. Auditory cortex: Located in the temporal lobe, it interprets auditory signals as sound.

 

Mnemonic to Remember the Sequence:

 

Even Cats Often Like Interesting Music Activities:

 

  • E: Eighth nerve
  • C: Cochlear nucleus
  • O: Olivary complex
  • L: Lateral lemniscus
  • I: Inferior colliculus
  • M: Medial geniculate body
  • A: Auditory cortex

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is: 

 

Eighth nerve → Cochlear nucleus → Olivary complex → Lateral lemniscus → Inferior colliculus → Medial geniculate body → Auditory cortex.

choices.text: Intracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation
Extracapsular cataract extraction plus intraocular lens implantation

questions.text: A 68-year-old female Raina Vohra presents with gradual onset of blurred vision, glare sensitivity, and difficulty with night driving over the past year. On examination, visual acuity is 20/80 in the right eye and 20/60 in the left eye. Slit-lamp examination reveals bilateral opacification of the crystalline lenses with cortical and nuclear changes. Fundoscopic examination is unremarkable, with no evidence of retinal pathology. Which of the following surgical options is most commonly used for the treatment of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phacoemulsification plus intraocular lens implantation

 

Phacoemulsification is the most advanced type of cataract surgery where the complications and surgery timings are minimal, with better anatomical and functional results.

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD in a state of euphoria. He was smiling and talking softly when he came in, then he was quiet for a while. He then seemed to be excited and suddenly started to laugh for no reason. How should the psychiatrist record his mood and affect?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Elevated mood and labile affect

questions.text: Following drug damages the area shown as * in the below image of organ of corti:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cisplatin

 

The image shows the organ of Corti, which contains hair cells that are crucial for hearing. The asterisk in the diagram is pointing to the outer hair cells, which play a vital role in amplifying sound and fine-tuning hearing sensitivity.

 

  • Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent that is ototoxic, and it specifically damages the outer hair cells of the organ of Corti. Cisplatin-induced hearing loss is dose-dependent and typically starts in the high-frequency range, gradually affecting lower frequencies. The damage is often permanent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Quinine: Quinine can affect hearing by damaging the stria vascularis, which is responsible for maintaining the ionic composition of endolymph, but it is not typically associated with damage to the outer hair cells.

 

Option B. Furosemide: Furosemide, a diuretic, is also known to affect the stria vascularis, leading to transient hearing loss, but it does not primarily damage the outer hair cells.

 

Option D. Gentamicin: Gentamicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is primarily vestibulotoxic (damaging to the balance organs in the inner ear), though other aminoglycosides like neomycin and kanamycin are cochleotoxic, affecting hearing. Gentamicin typically affects the vestibular system more than the cochlea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cisplatin is a chemotherapeutic agent that damages the outer hair cells of the organ of Corti, leading to hearing loss. This ototoxicity primarily affects high-frequency hearing and can be irreversible.

questions.text: Which of the following cylindrical lens combinations can be used to cure astigmatism that follows the rule?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) -3.00 DC x 180, +1.00 DC x 90

 

Astigmatism that "follows the rule" (or "with-the-rule" astigmatism) refers to a condition where the vertical meridian (90 degrees) has more refractive power than the horizontal meridian (180 degrees). In other words, with-the-rule astigmatism requires more correction along the horizontal axis (180 degrees) and less along the vertical axis (90 degrees).

 

To correct with-the-rule astigmatism:

 

  • The lens should have a minus (negative) cylindrical power at 180 degrees (horizontal axis).
  • A plus (positive) cylindrical power at 90 degrees (vertical axis) can also be used to balance the refractive power needed along each axis.

 

In this case:

 

  • -3.00 DC x 180, +1.00 DC x 90 follows the rule. The negative cylindrical power at 180 degrees and the positive cylindrical power at 90 degrees appropriately address with-the-rule astigmatism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

With-the-rule astigmatism correction typically requires a negative cylindrical lens power at 180 degrees and a positive cylindrical lens power at 90 degrees to compensate for the natural curvature of the cornea.

choices.text: Lesion of the dorsal columns on the right side
Lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus on the right side
Right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a bar fight during which he received a knife wound to his neck. The patient is in moderate distress but is alert and can follow commands. Vital signs are stable. Neurologic examination shows right-sided hemiplegia. Loss of proprioception and vibratory sensation is present below the C8 dermatome on the right side. On the left side, there is loss of pain and temperature sensation below the T2 dermatome. MRI of this patient's spine will most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Right-sided hemisection of the spinal cord

questions.text: A 25-year-old male-to-female transgender patient seeks surgical intervention to feminize her voice. Which type of Isshiki thyroplasty is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Type IV thyroplasty

 

Type IV thyroplasty is a lengthening thyroplasty used to feminize the voice by increasing the tension on the vocal cords. This procedure raises the pitch of the voice, which is ideal for male-to-female transgender patients or females with a low-pitched, "male-like" voice (androphonia).

 

Key points:

 

  • Type IV thyroplasty elongates the vocal cords by tightening the cricothyroid muscle, leading to a higher-pitched voice.
  • It is commonly used for feminization of the voice in male-to-female transgender patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I thyroplasty: Type I thyroplasty is a medialization thyroplasty, used for patients with unilateral vocal cord paralysis to bring the paralyzed vocal cord closer to the midline. It is not intended for pitch modification.

 

Option B. Type II thyroplasty: Type II thyroplasty is a lateralization thyroplasty, used for bilateral vocal cord paralysis to improve airway function by separating the vocal cords. It is not related to voice feminization or pitch modulation.

 

Option C. Type III thyroplasty: Type III thyroplasty is a shortening thyroplasty, used to lower the pitch of the voice. It is suitable for patients with puberphonia or for female-to-male transgender patients to achieve a deeper voice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type IV thyroplasty is the procedure of choice for voice feminization, as it lengthens the vocal cords and raises the pitch, ideal for male-to-female transgender patients or individuals with androphonia.

questions.text: A 24-year-old psychiatry patient is extremely interested in everything the physician says, exclaiming, “Wow, doctor, you really understand me, you’re the best!” She tells the physician about the verbal abuse that she suffered during her childhood from her mother. She says that she currently feels empty inside, like she has no direction. She discusses the large number of tumultuous relationships that she has had throughout her life, giving vague reasons as to why they have not worked out. When the physician suggests that her personality structure may be to blame, she screams, “You’re just like the rest of them!” and runs out. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Amongst which of the following conditions is the given instrument used?
In BPPV, which of the following canals is most commonly affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Posterior semicircular canal

 

Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV) is a condition characterized by episodes of vertigo triggered by changes in head position. It is caused by dislodged otoliths (calcium carbonate crystals) that move into one of the semicircular canals, disrupting the normal flow of endolymph and leading to inappropriate signaling of head movements.

 

The posterior semicircular canal is the most commonly affected canal in BPPV, accounting for the majority of cases. This is due to its anatomical orientation and the effect of gravity, which makes it more prone to the accumulation of displaced otoliths.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior semicircular canal: This canal is the least commonly affected in BPPV. Also referred to as the superior canal, it accounts for a small percentage of BPPV cases.

 

Option B. Lateral semicircular canal: This canal, also known as the horizontal canal, is the second most commonly affected canal in BPPV. It is less frequently involved than the posterior canal.

 

Option D. Horizontal semicircular canal: This is another name for the lateral semicircular canal, which, as mentioned, is the second most commonly affected in BPPV, but not the most common.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In BPPV, the posterior semicircular canal is most commonly affected due to its anatomical orientation, which makes it more susceptible to the dislodgment and accumulation of otoliths.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with type 2 diabetes was brought to the OPD by his wife after he began talking about aliens who were trying to steal his soul. He often stops talking mid-sentence and frequently scans the room for aliens. His wife reported he started expressing these ideas a few months ago, but they have become more severe and he had become isolated from his peers. Which of the following drugs should not be used in this patient?
A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

The provided audiogram shows a significant air-bone gap, which indicates conductive hearing loss. In addition, there is a notch at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction curve, which is characteristic of Carhart's notch, a hallmark of otosclerosis.

 

Otosclerosis is a condition where abnormal bony growth occurs around the stapes bone in the middle ear, causing conductive hearing loss. It is more common in women and can often become noticeable after pregnancy due to hormonal changes. The conductive hearing loss seen in the audiogram is typical, with air conduction being more affected than bone conduction.

 

Key Audiometric Findings for Otosclerosis:

 

  • Carhart’s notch: A dip at 2000 Hz in the bone conduction threshold.
  • Air-bone gap: Air conduction is worse than bone conduction, indicating conductive hearing loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ototoxicity: Typically affects high frequencies and presents with sensorineural hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option B. Meniere disease: Usually presents with low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss and fluctuating hearing loss, not conductive hearing loss.

 

Option D. Noise-induced hearing loss: Typically presents with a dip at 4000 Hz, indicating high-frequency hearing loss, which is not observed in this audiogram.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otosclerosis is characterized by conductive hearing loss, a significant air-bone gap, and Carhart’s notch at 2000 Hz on the audiogram. It commonly affects women, especially after pregnancy, due to hormonal influences on bone metabolism. The treatment of choice is stapedotomy.

questions.text: A 30 year old female came with complaints of hardness of hearing which was gradually progressive. On examination, tympanic membrane was intact but slight haziness was noticed. Rinne was negative on right side and weber lateralised to the right ear. A pure tone audiometry was advised. Which of the following audiogram belongs to the above patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B)

 

 

This patient presents with conductive hearing loss on the right side, as indicated by the negative Rinne's test (bone conduction better than air conduction) and Weber's test lateralizing to the right ear. The tympanic membrane's slight haziness suggests a possible underlying middle ear pathology, such as otosclerosis or chronic otitis media, which commonly cause conductive hearing loss.

 

  • Audiogram B shows a classic pattern of conductive hearing loss, where the bone conduction thresholds are within the normal range, but the air conduction thresholds are significantly worse, indicating an air-bone gap. This pattern matches the clinical findings of the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Audiogram A: This shows normal hearing, as both air and bone conduction thresholds are within the normal range. This does not match the patient's clinical findings of hearing loss.

 

Audiogram C: This audiogram shows sensorineural hearing loss, as both air and bone conduction thresholds are elevated but close to each other, with no significant air-bone gap. This does not match the clinical picture of conductive hearing loss.

 

Audiogram D: This audiogram suggests mixed hearing loss, with both air and bone conduction thresholds elevated and an air-bone gap present. While there is some overlap with conductive hearing loss, this does not precisely match the patient's findings of pure conductive loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In conductive hearing loss, bone conduction thresholds are typically normal, while air conduction thresholds are impaired, leading to an air-bone gap on audiometry. The negative Rinne's test and Weber's test lateralizing to the affected ear help confirm the diagnosis.

choices.text: Anterior spinal artery of the lumbosacral region

questions.text: A 64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to left lower extremity weakness. The patient was asymptomatic when he went to bed the night before, but he has had difficulty standing after waking up today. Temperature is 37°C (98.6° F), blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and pulse is 110/min and irregularly irregular. Left lower extremity examination shows motor power is 0/5, deep tendon reflexes are 3+, and Babinski sign is present. Right lower extremity examination is normal. An abnormality in which of the following structures is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Right anterior cerebral artery

questions.text: A 12 years old boy receiving long term treatment for spring catarrh, developed defective vision in both eyes. The likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior subcapsular cataract

 

The boy is likely on long-term steroid therapy for spring catarrh (vernal keratoconjunctivitis), which is a common allergic eye condition. Chronic use of corticosteroids is a well-known cause of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC), a type of toxic cataract. 

 

 

PSC affects the posterior part of the lens and can significantly impair vision, especially under bright light or when reading. It is one of the major side effects of long-term steroid use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinopathy of prematurity: This condition occurs in premature infants due to abnormal retinal vascular development. It is unrelated to long-term steroid use or spring catarrh.

 

Option C. Optic neuritis: While optic neuritis causes defective vision, it is an inflammatory condition of the optic nerve unrelated to steroid therapy or spring catarrh.

 

Option D. Vitreous hemorrhage: This condition involves bleeding into the vitreous humor, often associated with trauma, diabetes, or retinal conditions, but not linked to spring catarrh or steroid use.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Long-term steroid use, commonly prescribed for conditions like spring catarrh, can lead to the development of posterior subcapsular cataract, a toxic cataract that significantly affects vision.

choices.text: Psychological therapy to help the patient adjust to his biological gender

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the paediatrician by his father because he has been “acting like a girl.” When questioned alone, the patient states that he is uncomfortable with his life. He states that he has always had more feminine interests than most of his same-gender friends. He tries to fit in, but he simply feels more comfortable when he is hanging out with females and playing with dolls. The patient confesses that he has, for most of his life, believed that he should have been born as a girl. What is the best initial treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Psychological therapy to help the patient adjust to his biological gender

choices.text: Retracted to the level of the annulus
Retraction touching the incus or stapes

questions.text: Grade III Sade retraction of pars tensa refers to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retraction adherent to the promontory

 

Grade III retraction in the Sade classification system describes a retraction of the pars tensa (the tense portion of the tympanic membrane) that has progressed to the point where the tympanic membrane is in contact with the promontory. The promontory is a bony structure of the inner ear, and in this stage, the retraction of the eardrum has advanced significantly towards the medial aspect of the middle ear.

 

The Sade classification helps clinicians evaluate the severity of tympanic membrane retraction:

 

  • Grade I: Retraction of the tympanic membrane towards the malleus, making it more prominent.
  • Grade II: Retraction of the tympanic membrane touching the incus or stapes.
  • Grade III: Retraction reaching and adhering to the promontory.
  • Grade IV: Complete atelectasis, where the tympanic membrane is draped across the middle ear and may involve ossicular necrosis.

 

In Grade III, the tympanic membrane has moved deeply into the middle ear cavity and adheres to the promontory, indicating significant structural retraction and potential compromise of middle ear function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retracted to the level of the annulus: This describes an earlier stage of retraction, often associated with minor retraction or Grade I, not Grade III.

 

Option B. Retraction touching the incus or stapes: This describes Grade II retraction, where the tympanic membrane touches the incus or stapes but has not yet reached the promontory.

 

Option D. Retraction involving the malleus head: This describes Grade I retraction, where the tympanic membrane is retracted onto the malleus head, indicating a milder retraction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Grade III Sade retraction of the pars tensa refers to the tympanic membrane being adherent to the promontory in the middle ear. This stage reflects a significant retraction of the tympanic membrane.

questions.text: Identify the disease and procedure being performed:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Keratoconus- C3R

 

The image shows a cornea illuminated with green light (from riboflavin dye) and exposed to ultraviolet (UV-A) radiation. A lid speculum keeps the eye open. This appearance is characteristic of Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking (C3R or CXL), a procedure performed to treat keratoconus.

 

Keratoconus is a progressive, non-inflammatory thinning disorder of the cornea that causes it to become conical in shape, leading to:

 

  • Irregular astigmatism
  • Distorted and blurred vision
  • Progressive myopia

 

Typical presentation:

 

  • Young adults with frequent change of glasses
  • Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy
  • Munson’s sign (bulging of lower lid on downgaze)
  • Fleischer’s ring and Vogt’s striae on slit-lamp examination

 

About the Procedure – C3R / Corneal Collagen Cross-Linking:

 

Purpose: To strengthen corneal collagen and halt further thinning.

 

Steps:

 

  1. The corneal epithelium is removed (in the standard "epi-off" technique).
  2. Riboflavin (vitamin B2) drops are applied to saturate the corneal stroma.
  3. The cornea is then irradiated with UV-A light (365 nm) for about 30 minutes.
  4. The UV-A activates riboflavin, creating cross-links between collagen fibers, which increase corneal stiffness and stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cataract – Phacoemulsification: Not related. This is an intraocular procedure where the lens is emulsified and aspirated using ultrasound.

 

Option B. Corneal Ulcer – Fluorescein staining: Shows green fluorescence of epithelial defects under cobalt blue light but does not involve UV-A exposure or riboflavin.

 

Option D. Myopia – LASIK: Uses an excimer laser to reshape the cornea after creating a corneal flap. It is refractive surgery, not cross-linking.

choices.text: GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size low
GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged
GH low, IGF-1 unchanged, adenoma size low
GH unchanged, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the OPD following transsphenoidal resection of a growth hormone secreting pituitary adenoma. Three months ago, the patient was diagnosed with acromegaly. MRI of the pituitary showed a 14 mm sellar mass pressing on the optic chiasm and extending into the right cavernous sinus. The surgeon was able to only partially resect the pituitary mass because of the extension into the right cavernous sinus. Medical therapy for acromegaly with octreotide is planned. Which of the following changes are likely to occur following octreotide treatment in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size low 

 

Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue that suppresses growth hormone (GH) secretion from pituitary adenomas. This leads to a decrease in both GH and insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) levels. Additionally, octreotide often causes tumor shrinkage, resulting in decreased adenoma size.

 

Other Options:


Option B. GH low, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged: Adenoma size usually decreases with octreotide treatment.

 

Option C. GH low, IGF-1 unchanged, adenoma size low: IGF-1 levels typically decrease along with GH.

 

Option D. GH unchanged, IGF-1 low, adenoma size unchanged: GH levels decrease first; unchanged GH with low IGF-1 is unlikely.

questions.text: A patient presents with mental confusion, visual and auditory hallucinations, perceived changes of body shape, swelling of the tongue and a fear of impending death after he was treated for primary chancre of syphilis with an intramuscular injection. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: High grades of fever may be seen
Patient should be kept in supine position for better breathing

questions.text: Identify the image. Which is false regarding the condition with this finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient should be kept in supine position for better breathing

 

The image depicts the "thumb sign" on a lateral neck X-ray, which is characteristic of acute epiglottitis. Acute epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition caused by bacterial infections, such as Haemophilus influenzae or Streptococcus species. The swelling of the epiglottis can obstruct the airway, causing respiratory distress.

 

  • Inspiratory stridor is a hallmark symptom due to airway obstruction, which is correct.
  • High fever is commonly associated with the acute bacterial infection of the epiglottis, making option B correct.
  • The supine position should be avoided in these patients because lying down can cause the swollen epiglottis to fall backward, worsening the airway obstruction. The preferred position is the tripod position, where the patient leans forward to keep the airway open. Therefore, option C is false.
  • Systemic antibiotics are an essential part of the treatment to combat the bacterial infection, making option D correct.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inspiratory stridor is seen: This is correct as inspiratory stridor is a common symptom due to airway narrowing caused by the swollen epiglottis.

 

Option B. High grades of fever may be seen: This is correct as fever is typically present in bacterial infections like epiglottitis.

 

Option D. Treatment includes systemic antibiotics: This is correct because systemic antibiotics are crucial in managing bacterial epiglottitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute epiglottitis, patients should not be placed in a supine position as it can worsen airway obstruction. Instead, they should be allowed to sit in a tripod position to keep the airway as open as possible. Systemic antibiotics are essential to treat the bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 35-year-old immunocompetent man presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and thick nasal discharge. Examination reveals nasal polyposis and eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspergillus fumigatus

 

The clinical presentation and findings are characteristic of Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS), a condition seen in immunocompetent individuals. The hallmarks include:

 

  • Nasal polyposis.
  • Eosinophilic mucin without evidence of tissue invasion.
  • Thick nasal discharge and nasal obstruction.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common fungal organism responsible for AFRS. It induces an allergic reaction rather than direct invasion, leading to mucosal inflammation and polyposis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida albicans: Candida is more commonly associated with oral thrush or systemic fungal infections in immunocompromised individuals. It does not cause allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

 

Option C. Cryptococcus neoformans: Cryptococcus is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals, particularly in association with cryptococcal meningitis or systemic cryptococcosis. It is not a cause of AFRS.

 

Option D. Mucor species: Mucor species are responsible for mucormycosis, a highly invasive fungal infection that occurs in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those with diabetes or on immunosuppressive therapy). Mucormycosis involves tissue invasion, which is absent in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common organism causing allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS), a condition seen in immunocompetent individuals characterized by nasal polyposis and eosinophilic mucin without tissue invasion.

questions.text: Risk factors for primary open-angle glaucoma are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Young age

 

Young age is not a risk factor for POAG; instead, the disease is more commonly seen in older adults.


Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) is often asymptomatic and typically affects individuals over a certain age.

 

Other Options:

 

Risk factors include :

 

Option A. Family history of glaucoma: This is a known risk factor, as genetics play a significant role in POAG, with those having family members with glaucoma at higher risk.

 

Option B. High myopia: Individuals with high levels of myopia (nearsightedness) are at increased risk for POAG due to the structural changes in the eye associated with severe myopia.

 

Option C. Hypertension: High blood pressure is also considered a risk factor, as it can affect intraocular pressure and overall vascular health, contributing to the development of glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Young age is not a risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma, while family history, high myopia, and hypertension are.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman is brought to the hospital after her daughter found her unresponsive in the morning. The patient and her daughter walked extensively during a family outing the previous day; the patient then skipped dinner and went to bed as soon as they returned home. Medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus managed with an oral medication. The patient is diaphoretic and responds only to pain. Blood glucose is 34 mg/dl. Her condition rapidly improves after administration of an intravenous bolus of dextrose, but she becomes confused again several hours later. Repeat blood glucose is 39 mg/dl. Which of the following medications is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?

The image below shows a patient with limited tongue movement and a visible band of tissue extending from the tongue to the floor of the mouth. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this condition in infants?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impaired breastfeeding

 

This patient has ankyloglossia (tongue-tie), a condition in which a short or tight lingual frenulum restricts tongue movement. This can lead to:

 

  1. Difficulty breastfeeding:
    • During breastfeeding, the tongue must elevate and press against the palate to create a seal and push the milk bolus backward. Limited tongue mobility prevents effective latching and swallowing, leading to poor feeding in infants.
  2. Speech issues:
    • While complete speech delay is uncommon, certain sounds (e.g., "n," "t," "d") that require tongue elevation may be difficult to pronounce.
  3. Dental issues:
    • If untreated, this condition may eventually lead to poor oral hygiene and dental problems like dental caries, but it is not the primary concern in infants.
  4. Not associated with cancer:
    • There is no link between ankyloglossia and oropharyngeal cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Speech delay: Ankyloglossia may cause difficulty in pronouncing specific sounds but does not typically result in overall speech delay.

 

Option C. Dental caries: While poor oral hygiene may develop in older children with severe ankyloglossia, this is not a significant consequence in infancy.

 

Option D. Oropharyngeal cancer: Ankyloglossia has no connection to cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ankyloglossia in infants most commonly results in impaired breastfeeding due to restricted tongue movement, which affects latching and swallowing.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the outpatient clinic for a checkup. She reached all developmental milestones until the age of 24 months. Since then, she has become more distant and less socially engaging. Verbal language consists mostly of grunting and loud nonverbal yelling, a severe decline from her toddler years when she could speak in three- to four-word sentences. She has never been completely toilet trained and has difficulty following verbal commands from her caregivers. What is the most likely disorder in this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Childhood disintegrative disorder

 

Childhood disintegrative disorder (CDD), also known as Heller’s syndrome, is a rare pervasive developmental disorder characterized by normal early development (for at least the first 2 years) followed by marked regression in multiple areas of functioning.

 

This child had normal milestones until age 2, after which she experienced a loss of language, social engagement, and bladder/bowel control — classic for CDD.

 

Key Features of Childhood Disintegrative Disorder:

 

  • Normal development for at least 2 years after birth.
  • Onset of regression typically occurs between ages 2–10 years.
  • Significant loss of previously acquired skills in:
    • Language (e.g., loss of speech)
    • Social interaction
    • Motor skills
    • Toilet training / bowel-bladder control
  • May show stereotyped behaviours or restricted interests similar to autism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Asperger’s syndrome: Involves social interaction difficulties and restricted interests but no significant language or cognitive delay; development is continuous, not regressive.

 

Option B. Autism (Autism Spectrum Disorder): Deficits in social communication and restrictive behaviors are present from early development (usually before age 3), not after a period of normal functioning.

 

Option D. Rett’s disorder: Occurs almost exclusively in girls, with normal early development followed by loss of motor and speech skills and stereotyped hand movements (wringing, clapping); caused by MECP2 gene mutation on the X chromosome.

choices.text: Topical pilocarpine and Nd:YAG 532nm laser capsulotomy
Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Femtosecond laser Iridotomy
Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG 1064nm laser Iridotomy

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman attends the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. She says that her right eye is painful and red. Vision is reduced. She is longsighted and wears glasses for near and distance vision. She is generally fit. There is no family history of medical problems. On examination the emergency doctor finds the vision to be reduced to counting fingers in the right eye. The eye is red, the cornea appears cloudy and edematous, and the pupil is oval and dilated on the affected side. No view of the fundus is obtained. What are the immediate and definitive treatment options:
questions.solution: Ans. C) Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG 1064nm laser Iridotomy

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of sudden onset of floaters in the left eye accompanied by small flashes of light. His past medical history is significant for treated hypertension, and he has no other medical problems. Dilated funduscopy reveals no abnormalities, and visual acuity is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD)

 

Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) is a common condition in older adults where the vitreous gel inside the eye begins to liquefy and separate from the retina. This separation can cause floaters (specks or cobweb-like images in the field of vision) and photopsia (flashes of light) as the vitreous pulls on the retina. In this case, the patient's normal visual acuity and the absence of fundus abnormalities on examination support the diagnosis of PVD, as it does not directly impact vision or cause retinal damage. PVD is usually benign, but follow-up is necessary to rule out complications such as retinal tears or detachment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinal detachment: Retinal detachment can also present with floaters and flashes of light, but it would typically cause visual field defects, and abnormalities would be seen on fundus examination. Vision may also be affected if the macula is involved.

 

Option C. Vitreous hemorrhage: Vitreous hemorrhage would cause visual disturbances due to blood within the vitreous, impairing visibility on fundus examination. The fundus would not appear normal, and visual acuity may be reduced.

 

Option D. Age-related macular degeneration (AMD): AMD is associated with gradual vision loss, particularly central vision, rather than the sudden onset of floaters and flashes. Fundus examination would typically reveal changes in the macula, such as drusen or retinal pigment abnormalities, which are not present here.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Posterior vitreous detachment is indicated by floaters and flashes with a normal fundus and visual acuity. It is a benign condition but requires monitoring to rule out complications like retinal tears.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother. She is concerned because although tall, her son looks much younger than his peers and shows no signs of "masculinity." On physical examination, the boy has poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics. He is unable to distinguish smells but has good visual acuity. Which of the following pathways is most likely defective in this patient?
Surface ectoderm gives rise to all of the following structures except ?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anterior layer of iris

 

The anterior layer of the iris is not derived from the surface ectoderm. It develops from the neural ectoderm, which is associated with tissues that have a closer link to the nervous system, including the optic nerve, retina, iris, and ciliary body.

 

The surface ectoderm is responsible for forming various structures that are visible on the surface of the body or eye. Structures derived from the surface ectoderm in the eye include the lens, corneal epithelium, conjunctival epithelium, lacrimal gland, and eyelids. These structures develop from the surface ectoderm because they are situated externally or derived from the outer layer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The surface ectoderm gives rise to external eye structures like the lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium, while the anterior layer of the iris is derived from the neural ectoderm.

 

Mnemonic for neural crest derivatives: “CREST”

 

  • C: Corneal endothelium
  • R: Retina
  • E: Endothelium of cornea
  • S: Stroma (of cornea) and Sclera
  • T: Trabecular meshwork

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the OPD due to advanced prostate cancer with bone metastases. For the last 4 months, he has been treated with a GnRH agonist, which has significantly reduced his bone pain. However, the patient now reports discomfort at the anterior chest wall. Physical examination reveals bilateral, mildly tender enlargement of the breast tissue behind the nipple-areolar complex. Early initiation of which of the following medications would be most appropriate for preventing this patient's breast symptoms?
